intro: Chelystachya bancoensis, commonly known as the Banko grass, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the grass family Poaceae and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, clustered inflorescences that are typically greenish or brownish in color. It is often found in wetland or marshy habitats, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Due to its ecological significance and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation areas.
